Review.Titre: Stellar Shared Business Hosting - Subpar Technical Setup
Review.Contenu: After hearing great reviews of the Namecheap Stellar shared hosting I decided to give it a try on my different sites. Overall everything seemed fantastic for the first few days, until I decided to enable the Litespeed (LS) CDN network on my websites. From previous experience, when LS CDN is optimized loading is lightning fast, so why not use it here? As all Namecheap servers run off LS servers I figured connecting to their CDN servers would be a simple and beautifully efficient process. Unfortunately that turned out to be a wildly optimistic take. Upon enabling the CDN I started getting cascading 520 errors saying (browser couldn't reach the origin server). Upon reading the documentation, I saw they recommended whitelisting several dozen IP addresses used to process CDN requests. At first, I found it strange that these IP's weren't already whitelisted as they are required to fully utilize LS server capabilities. No problem, I thought, will just contact support and get this worked out quickly. Nope, this simply started a process of dozens of messages between myself, LS techs, and Namecheap techs. After several weeks, it was determined that Namecheap was unwilling to make any changes to solve this problem. They stated that upgrading to a VPS ($$$) was the only possible way to whitelist the CDN IP’s and thus fully utilize the servers. Ultimately this means that a decent percentage of server performance is completely unavailable to shared host users. Of course, you can also just pay a third party CDN provider extra money each month for something that is already included at the Enterprise level by default for just using their LS servers.After a bit of research it was discovered that Namecheap offers an in-house SuperSonic CDN. Learning this made it abundantly clear that by handicapping the LS CDN, it easily funnels many new and inexperienced users into purchasing their add-on service. To be fair, I understand this from a sales perspective. I would hope though for future users they make it abundantly clear at sign-up that their shared servers are completely incompatible with LS's CDN service. This would seemingly save many frustrated customers from even signing up in the first place if they are searching from companies that utilize LS servers and their performance.

Review.Titre: TOO CHEAP?
Review.Contenu: Well, here we go again: I need to find a new registrar. I've been a Namecheap customer 6.5 years now and I'm appalled to find that they've cut off ALL direct contact with customers. Not only have they done away with talking to people on the phone - a long time ago, apparently - but trying to use their "chat" system simply produces a message saying NO, you can only submit a "ticket." The more I dig into this, the more mysterious it gets. OK, supposedly their customer support department consists of two folks from Ukraine? Or, they have offices in Phoenix and/or L.A.? What? MEMO TO NAMECHEAP: Whatever the heck you're doing, which seems to be going down a slippery slope of the worst practices of tech industry culture, you can't run a biz as CHEAP as possible and expect vast numbers of people to stick with you no matter what. I'm sure you don't care about my piddly account, but either turn your chat AND phone back on or I'm out of here. In other words, HIRE HUMANS.

Review.Titre: Products and services on the slide
Review.Contenu: I've been using namecheap for a while but their products and services have steadily degraded over time and using their platform has increasing become frustrating.Their verification mechanism when logging in is farcical and doesn't work half the time. Oh, and once locked, not even their help desk can reset it. What a joke. And trying to set up multiple domains across their accounts is a multi-day headache. Also, FTP doesn't work, every time the login details fail. And following their copious amounts of documentation to do the most basic of tasks is painful.But the most frustrating part of their service is dealing with their tech support. They will often jump from one assistant to another without warning and assistants are not processing what has already been explained and so often one may have to go over the same details multiple times.I think the problem with namecheap like any large hosting provider is they get complacent and think they can throw a call centre when they struggle to service their customers. Unfortunately, this leads to subpar service which is time consuming to deal with and is off putting.I think it's time to find a new host although I'm wondering if going back to hosting my own servers may be less headache-inducing. Even though it is more work at least I'm in control.I can't really recommend namecheap any more.

Review.Titre: Estonia based customer verification system
Review.Contenu: I had to create a ticket because my phone number changed tied to 2-factor authentication and I could not log in. I totally appreciate the need to verify my identity. They asked me to provide the last four digits and expiration date of the credit card I used 3 years ago to pay for my domain. When I wasn't able to provide that information (go figure), I was told I needed to verify using veriff.com. A site that has you upload a government issued ID and a selfie. A quick Google search shows it is based in Estonia and has a 1.9 rating on TrustPilot. Need I say more. NameCheap lives up to its name of being cheap, but it sucks the moment you have an issue.Update based on final outcome:In the vein of being fair, I am updating my review after considerable (no joke about 12 rounds) back and forth with NameCheap. It took a pretty strong threat involving advice from an attorney, but I was able to get them to verify my identity by providing a utility bill as opposed to using veriff.com. If they read this, I would advise they stop advertising that PCI compliance keeps my data safe because it does no such thing. PCI compliance only serves the purpose of protecting a credit card number, and it is a self-regulated organization set up by credit card companies.I do commend the organization for quick responses, but it is clear most of those responding only have the authority to copy and paste templated sentences. They repeatedly ignored my requests to be transferred to a supervisor. I am hoping not to repeat this process, but I would recommend asking to be transferred to Risk Management as quickly as possible. My issue was resolved in one round of communication with that department.

Review.Titre: They charged my expired card
Review.Contenu: While with Namecheap I didn't have a problem with them. However when I decided not to renew my subscription was where the problem started. I received an email stating "We've noticed that your credit card has expired. This means, unfortunately, that the products you have set to auto-renew between April 10 and May 09, won't be successfully renewed." I thought great they can't renew and I don't want to renew so good. I did log in to make sure the card on file did indeed expire and it did. So I left it. However I was still charged. When I went to dispute it I was informed that it was more than 120 hours (5 days) after they charged the account so they couldn't refund it. This was on day 6. They said they charged the expired card and the bank sent them the updated card information and still charged my account. If someone from the company actually reads these then you should improve this process. The email sent clearly stated it could not renew the account. No where in the email did it say it was possible that they could indeed still charge the account. While I was chatting with customer service I was sent a link to an article apparently on their website stating that they could. That also should have been linked in the email. How am I supposed to know to look for these things before I even have a problem? They got 2 stars because the customer service people were nice or at least seemed to be and this is also a bank issue. Otherwise they would have gotten 1. Will take it up with my bank tomorrow (Monday).

Review.Titre: Avoid for web hosting
Review.Contenu: I've used namecheap for domain registration for more than 13 years. Both stars are for the registration service, they've been fine for that and for years I recommended them to people. I deeply regret the recommendations after switching my shared website hosting to them and seeing how they try to exploit technical ignorance.Every web host in the same price range offers free SSL - a security certificate to enable greater trust on the internet. Every host offers it free because they also get it free, using a tool called "let's encrypt". Namecheap do not offer free SSL. They pretend they do for 1 year, then they plan to charge ~$12 each for certificate they've "given" you for the first year. Depending on your domain setup, this could be up to 50 additional $12 charges after the first year ($600+). Not very honest! I saw that the SSL was not free prior to signup, so I asked a sales rep to confirm I'd be able to use let's encrypt (the free service every other host provides). I was told I could use it, so I signed up.My certificates were expiring ~50 days into my time with namecheap, so I set about installing let's encrypt. It should be very straightforward: run a script, then click a button saying you want SSL. Namecheap do not allow users of their shared hosting to execute that script. Fair enough as it's theoretically a security risk so surely a support agent will execute it for me instead, it'll only take a second or two. The support agent will not execute the script on my behalf. Instead they spend ~45 minutes on chat with me telling me to either use the "free" 1 year one (for the renewal I suppose) or telling me they can cancel my account but maybe no refund because I'm outside the 30 day window, or I can manually create and upload certificates myself.This is frustrating because it would be trivial for the agent to solve my issue (literal seconds, unless their systems are terrible). I thought the "cheap" in the name was their price, not the way they try to screw every penny out of users.Anyway, I'm kind of technical and I'm annoyed so I decide I'll manually generate certificates and upload them to last until I've used up my hosting and can move to a good web host who'll include free SSL like you'd expect. Here's another gross surprise: to manually generate a certificate, you need to prove it's your website - a sensible safety precaution. To prove you own the website you need to add a special code to the DNS record (a thing that tells the internet where your website lives). Namecheap disable the ability to add records to the DNS if they start with an underscore: "_". What a coincidence that the free SSL tool generates special codes that all start with an underscore!In summary: through greediness, laziness, or a combination, namecheap do not allow shared hosting customers to access the free SSL that most of the internet relies on to keep websites safe. Instead they try to trick/nickel and dime their customers, and appear to actively block/disable more technical users from accessing free SSL.Consequently as a long-time customer, I have to strongly recommend you avoid namecheap for web hosting, and also now consider that another domain registrar is probably a safer bet too.

Review.Contenu: I've been using Namecheap for quite a long time. It's a good choice to manage domains in my opinion. That's why I decided to try their hosting service, too. To clarify, I'm talking about a very simple STATIC site (no php or whatsoever, just pure html, js and css). The site usually takes over 60 seconds (!!!!) to load. I didn't believe it, so I made speed tests at Pingdom and GTmetrix targeting different locations around the world: the results were the same or even worse (sometimes 70-80sec to load). Hilarious.

This brought us a problem in the company and we had to abandon the project name for the domain that did not match.The only thing that gives it 2 stars and no less is the support service that always responded to me in a timely manner and spent hours with me doing tests when I had a problem.

Review.Titre: Namecheap would be 5-stars if it wasn't…
Review.Contenu: Namecheap would be 5-stars if it wasn't for their draconian password policy.Domain management is one of those things that you do rarely.  So who the heck remembers their password?A typical Namecheap experience starts with a locked account from 3 mis-tries.  Then, you have to go through the password reset rigmarole.  They send you an email, you click a link.  You reset your password, you can't use ANY of your previous passwords.  So you think of an unmemorable password just to get in (this right here is why no one can remember their passwords).  And then you try to log in, then you still can't because they want to send you a verification code, so you go check your email again and you plug in the code.All so you can add a CNAME record to point to some new URL.Other than this hideous blemish, Namecheap would otherwise be 5-stars.

Review.Titre: Customer Service Could Be Better, Good Otherwise
Review.Contenu: UPDATE: I heard from a supervisor at Namecheap and they apologized and gave me a small credit. So I upgraded my review to 4 stars. I am still under the impression that I probably won't be able to cancel a domain in the future. As far as I know, this isn't an issue with other domain providers. Otherwise, Namecheap is pretty good. The prices are low and there are a lot of different services and options. I do see room for improvement in the customer service area but this is true of most businesses now. ORIGINAL REVIEW: On May 7 I bought 2 new domains for my blog and podcast. As it turned out there were problems with each of the domains. Since I was well within the 5 day grace period, I contacted customer service on May 8th to cancel. I had to get up early the next morning so I didn't appreciate being kept on chat for almost an hour (multiple very long holds). I also REALLY didn't appreciate being accused of domain sampling (which I had never even heard of before). While I was waiting (and waiting) for the customer service person to rejoin the chat, I looked up domain sampling. I now understand that it is a form of fraud that usually involves using the entire 5 day grace period for nefarious purposes. I had these domains for 1 day.I have several domains and WordPress hosting through Namecheap. I don't ask to be treated like a valued customer. But being treated like a customer in the most basic sense - instead of a criminal - would have been nice.I have not found customer service helpful with issues with WordPress either.
